title: Overwhelmed by 'new arrivals', Denver residents organize to welcome migrant populations decently
summary: Colorado's capital city welcomed more than 38,500 migrants in one year. Many residents have come to their aid despite the Republicans exploiting the influx for their anti-migrant campaign.

title: Armenian Resistance fighter joins France's Panthéon heroes
summary: Missak Manouchian and his wife Mélinée entered the Parisian monument in a ceremony attended by roughly 2,000 figures and presided over by President Emmanuel Macron.

title: 'The people of Gaza are suffering severe mental trauma. They live in a state of permanent terror'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, Pascal Hundt, head of the International Committee of the Red Cross mission in Gaza, cautions that a major Israeli military offensive at Rafah would result in an 'absolute disaster.'

title: Pressure mounts on Rwanda over violence in DR Congo
summary: The US, one of Kigali's most valued allies, condemned violence by the M23 rebels, which the UN says are supported by Rwanda, after fighting flared near Goma.

title: Julian Assange's extradition on hold while judges deliberate after two days of hearings
summary: The founder of WikiLeaks faces 175 years in prison in the US, where he is charged with releasing hundreds of thousands of confidential documents. In the coming weeks, the British courts will have to decide whether or not to grant him a final appeal.

title: What we know about Russian pilot Maxim Kuzminov, who defected to Ukraine and is now believed to be dead
summary: Ukrainian military intelligence confirmed the death of the pilot without specifying either the place or the circumstances. According to 'El Pais,' he was murdered on February 13 near Alicante, in Spain.

title: Champions League: Porto shock Arsenal while Napoli and Barcelona draw
summary: Galeno scored deep into stoppage time to give Porto a 1-0 victory in the first leg of their Champions League last-16 tie while Robert Lewandowski and Victor Osimhen traded goals in a 1-1 draw.

title: G20: Brazil calls for reform of United Nations
summary: Brazil's foreign minister criticized the UN's inability to prevent global conflicts such as those playing out in Ukraine and the Gaza Strip, as his country kicked off its presidency of the Group of 20 nations.

title: California's no-holds-barred battle for the US Senate
summary: Adam Schiff is the favorite to fill the seat left vacant by the death of Dianne Feinstein. He has already raised some $35 million for his campaign.

title: Lawyers for US urge UK court to reject Assange extradition appeal
summary: Washington indicted the WikiLeaks founder multiple times between 2018 and 2020 over its publication of hundreds of thousands of secret military and diplomatic files on the US-led wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Eiffel Tower closed for third day due to strike
summary: The monument's operator has advised ticket holders to check its website before showing up, or to postpone their visit.

title: Manouchians' entry into the Panthéon: Who decides who gets France's highest honor?
summary: Voltaire, Victor Hugo, Marie Curie and Joséphine Baker are just some of the famed people who have entered into the Paris monument, an honor up to the discretion of the French president.

title: Bottled water: Foodwatch lodges complaint after revelations of prohibited treatments
summary: Foodwatch is set to take legal action following revelations of illegal purification techniques used on water sold as 'spring' or 'natural mineral.'

title: French people should be encouraged to eat less meat, study says
summary: What should the French eat to meet their country's environmental commitments? Less, but better quality meat, according to two organizations who hope to influence official health and nutrition recommendations.

title: How Biden attempts to qualify US support for Israel
summary: The US vetoed for the third time a draft UN resolution for an immediate ceasefire in the Gaza Strip. The White House proposed its own text, conditioning a ceasefire to the liberation of all hostages.

title: Polish farmers demand 'complete embargo' on Ukrainian produce
summary: Protesting farmers have denounced the explosion in their production costs which they say is unfair competition, a further sign that relations between Ukraine and its ally are strained.

title: China relies on transgenic monkeys for scientific research
summary: While the first genetically modified monkey, a macaque with a fluorescence gene, was born in 2001 in an American laboratory, today China is clearly at the forefront of genome manipulation and cloning.

title: Trump compares his legal troubles to Alexei Navalny persecution
summary: Former US president Donald Trump compared his own legal troubles with the persecution of Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny, who died in prison last week.

title: Japan paves the way for Ukraine's reconstruction
summary: Aware of the post-war economic stakes in the country, Tokyo mobilized Japan's major companies and announced a new aid package worth €4.2 billion.

title: Are the Lebrun brothers making table tennis popular again?
summary: Emerging as sports sensations and new media darlings, the table tennis players from Montpellier are contributing to the noticeable, albeit modest, resurgence of French table tennis.

title: Boeing ousts head of 737 MAX program weeks after Alaska Airlines incident
summary: Boeing announced that Ed Clark, who had been with the company for nearly 18 years and led the 737 program since early 2021, was leaving immediately.
